title: Tuesday, 28th March, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:02am

Hi there

PM11:02am

Strange day

PM11:02am

There's lots of stuff around but it's all really bit-y

11:02 am
PM11:03am

And my inbox is full of crap

PM11:03am

Bryce -- have you noticed this huge spike in PR stuff trying to get us to print advertorials?

PM11:04am

It's like a load of corporates have come back from some Buzzfeed training course

11:04 am
PM11:04am

And they've been told: "Yeah, we can write the news ourselves!"

PM11:04am

But they don't know how to do that

PM11:04am

So they pay some PR £3k per 1000 words

11:04 am
PM11:04am

And then they send them to us

PM11:05am

And we just say "no" and move the crap to the trash

PM11:05am

How long do you think it will be before they get the message?

11:05 am
PM11:05am

I'd share some but ive just spent 10 minutes trashing them all

undefined
PM11:06am

So, index flat again

11:05 am
PM11:06am

Omg smile

PM11:06am

PM11:06am

And one leading one -- albeit without much price reaction

11:06 am
PM11:06am

....

PM11:06am

Tesco

PM11:06am

Do we have to be careful about how we write this?

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Censored

PM11:07am

Certain legal things that we shouldn't even mention on here

PM11:07am

Censored

11:06 am
BE11:07am

Right.

PM11:07am

I'm teasing you on the right

PM11:07am

Have the FCA statement

11:07 am
PM11:07am

The Financial Conduct Authority (‘FCA’) today announces that Tesco plc and Tesco Stores Limited (‘Tesco’) have agreed that they committed market abuse in relation to a trading update published on 29 August 2014, which gave a false or misleading impression about the value of publicly traded Tesco shares and bonds. Tesco have agreed to pay compensation to investors who purchased Tesco shares and bonds on or after the 29 August 2014 and who still held those securities when the statement was corrected on 22 September 2014.

This is the first time the FCA has used its powers under section 384 of the Financial Services and Markets Act to require a listed company to pay compensation for market abuse. Conduct by issuers in the primary market affects the integrity of investments and securing compensation is an important step in ensuring effective access to redress for those investors, especially for the very significant number of retail investors that this redress scheme will benefit, whether they invested privately or through participation in a pension fund or similar investment.

PM11:08am

Andrew Bailey, Chief Executive of the FCA, said: “Dissemination of information that gives a false or misleading impression as to traded securities harms the integrity of our markets. The FCA is committed to UK markets being fair, transparent and thus competitive. Tesco and its board are doing the right thing here, taking appropriate responsibility and agreeing to rectify the consequences of the misconduct. They have cooperated fully with us and this sets a good example for the market and so is a good outcome for Tesco and investors.”

On 29 August 2014, Tesco plc published a trading update in which it stated that it expected trading profit for the six months ending 23 August 2014 to be in the region of £1.1bn. On 22 September 2014, Tesco plc published a further trading update in which it announced that it had “identified an overstatement of its expected profit for the half year, principally due to the accelerated recognition of commercial income and delayed accrual of costs.” Tesco knew or could reasonably have been expected to know that the information in the 29 August 2014 announcement was false or misleading. In making this finding, the FCA does not suggest that the Tesco plc board knew or could reasonably have been expected to know that the information was false or misleading

PM11:08am

Actually, it's too bloody long

11:08 am
PM11:08am

Read the Final Notice yourself

PM11:08am

https://www.fca.or...ces/tesco-2017.pdf

BE11:08am

Tesco's statement is more brief, most notably saying that the FCA "expressly stated that it is not suggesting that the Tesco PLC Board of Directors knew, or could have reasonably be expected to have known, that the information contained in that trading statement was false or misleading".

11:09 am

PM11:09am

PM11:09am

But it's not open yet. End August is the target.

BE11:11am

11:12 am
BE11:12am

And you might get 24.5p per share and 4% annualised interest! Exciting huh?

BE11:12am

Anyway, that's the Watchdog bit of this covered.

BE11:13am

Here's some sellside to say "this is a welcome distraction moved into the rear view mirror but the Booker deal resistance remains an unknown issue."

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Take a moment to enjoy this first sentence from Clive Black at Shore.

BE11:13am

Tesco, the leading British supermarket group, announced welcome news, to our minds, today with the confirmation, following recent press speculation, that that its division, Tesco Stores Limited, has reached a Deferred Prosecution Agreement (DPA) with the UK Serious Fraud Office (SFO) regarding what it calls 'historic accounting practices'.

BE11:13am

How many commas? All the commas!

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Shore Capital welcomes the announcements of these agreements between Tesco and the UK authorities. We believe that Dave Lewis engaged in corporate wonders in keeping Tesco stable at the time of this crisis and all shareholders should be thankful for his skills in navigating the business through the most choppy of waters. The announcement of the settlements brings to an end, hopefully, a damaging chapter for the business so allowing for further focus on the current day job.

The latter, of course, now includes potentially more distraction, to our minds, with the proposed merger with Booker^ (BOK, Sell), on which we await the wisdom of the UK Competition & Markets Authority. In this respect we note with interest some dissenting institutional investor voices on this deal whilst we wonder quite whether Booker's share register today has the same composition as it did ahead of the suprise 'merger' announcement. Booker reports on Q4 trading on Thursday (30th March), whilst Tesco has preliminary results on the 12th April 2017.

PM11:14am

I appreciate the proper use of commas

BE11:14am

Sure, but Proust was more sparing with his clauses.

PM11:15am

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Here's Morgan Stanley, which is house broker.

BE11:19am

FY17 numbers are broadly in line with EPS 3% lower due to higher depreciation and tax. No change is expected to consensus FY18e adjusted EBITDA of £417m (MSe £422.5m). Divisionally, EBITDA was slightly below MSe in Roadside Assistance and Insurance Services offset by lower head office costs due to higher costs savings. Net Debt (£2.7bn) is 2.5% above MSe due to working capital outflow of £8m (MSe inflow of £20m), but this was driven by one off factors related to the treatment of pension and double cover provisions, and u/l cash flow characteristics of the membership model remain unchanged. As at the pre-close, the KPIs (retention, membership, # motor policies) are tracking positively. The investment case remains intact - ie cash flow, returns and debt levels should all improve from fiscal 2018e.

Tricky to understand, as a non-geologist, how competent persons' reports, can we so wildly wrong.

BE11:26am

And more to the point, why investors should trust them.

BE11:27am

I mean, here's the bit from the Genel-Vallares merger release in 2011.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

The Company is expected to be among the top three independent UK listed E&P companies by 2P reserves, with an estimated unrisked resource base of 1.4 billion boe, including proved and probable reserves of 356 million barrels. Current production is 41,000 barrels a day, projected to rise to 90,000 barrels by 2013.

Genel's biggest producing asset is the Taq Taq field where it has a 44 per cent. working interest and is joint operator. It holds a 25 per cent. stake in the smaller Tawke field, near the Turkish border which is operated by DNO. Their proven and probable gross reserves are estimated at 647 million and 286 million boe respectively under the McDaniel & Associates competent persons report to be included in the prospectus to be published in connection with the transaction.

BE11:28am

Now, I'm pretty sure Genel's not quite made those targets.

PM11:28am

http://www.mcdan.com/

11:28 am
BE11:28am

As to today, Taq Taq ... 59.1 mmbbls of 2p at end February 2017, vs 148m as of end 2016

BE11:28am

Consensus was at 88m, which everyone thought was being conservative.

BE11:29am

Because production terrible. As in terrible. As in, Taq Taq went from 2015’s 116kb/d to exit 2016 at 36,000 b/d.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Meaning Genel's withdrawn 2017 production guidance

BE11:30am

Which is less than useful when it has a debt flip coming up.

BE11:30am

Here's Canaccord.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

The market was braced for a disappointing update on Taq Taq reserves, but today's is notably worse than our expectations. We had assumed gross unrisked 94 mmbbls production from end '16, risked at 70%, to give, effectively, assumed recovery of 66 mmbbls from the start of this year. The 2P result is 10% below that, and we believe (from company guidance) that analyst consensus was for risked 2P reserves of about 85 mmbbls.
Furthermore, the continued dramatic production decline from 35 kbopd average in January to about 19 kbopd now, due to the water breakthrough in key producing wells, paints a gloomy picture. In January, Genel indicated a range of remediation activities - workovers, sidetracks, installation of ESPs, new development wells - but much appeared to be contingent on regular payments for exported crude. While this has improved a little this year, it is not yet clear that there is the predictability that Genel requires to make the necessary investments. Nor, considering the field performance over the past 18 months and the tone of the CPR - McDaniel states that there is "still significant uncertainty in Taq Taq oil reserves", do we think it reasonable to assume that the recovery of the 2P reserves can be achieved. In our view, the 1P reserves is a more sensible basis for valuation at this stage.

BE11:30am

We reduce our anticipated Taq Taq field recovery (from 1/1/17) to 54 mmbbls (10% below current 2P) and we increase the risk assigned to the field (to 50% from 70% CoS). This effectively assumes 27 mmbbls recovery from Taq Taq, about the current 1P reserves. As a result our NPV15 core producing value, and basis for our TP, is reduced to 63p/share (from 81p/share). We reiterate our HOLD rating with a downgraded TP of 60p/share (from 80p/share), and we note that the company has much to do to reassure the market about Taq Taq's remaining value and to progress the Miran/Bina Bawi gas project.

BE11:31am

And Jefferies.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Actually, not Jefferies. It's dull. Have UBS.

BE11:32am

Prior to today's announcement our Core NAV ex-KRG receivable (a reasonable anchor for the shares in our view, given uncertainty around continued KRG payments and the challenges in commercialising contingent resource in the region) was 81p/sh at UBSe $70/bbl LT Brent or 65p/sh at $60/bbl. Putting through today's downgrade would see these figures fall to c73p/sh and 59p/sh, all else being equal. Consensus NAVs are likely to fall further, in our view. Genel has also dropped its prior Taq Taq production guidance of 24-31kb/d gross, will now announce production on a monthly basis, and will take a $181m impairment with FY16 results on 30 March (adding to impairments to Chia Surkh and Miran previously flagged).

BE11:32am

Prepayment deals with trading houses earlier this year helped the KRG's fiscal position and allowed a restart of payments for exports. These payments are currently a ~$20m monthly cashflow stream for Genel although this figure is expected to fall with Taq Taq production this year. With net debt of $240m at end-16 and $675m of bonds maturing in early 2019 continued Taq Taq declines increase the Balance Sheet risk.

11:37 am

http://www.investe...1703280700126815A/

BE11:38am

BE11:38am

11:38 am
BE11:39am

Odd though. Never heard of it before except in weird darkwaters like football clubs.

BE11:39am

Anyway, here's Shore again.

BE11:39am

We view Redrow’s decision this morning to step away from making an offer for, or looking to merge with, Bovis^ (BVS, HOLD at 873p) as a positive development, as we set out in our note yesterday. As Redrow highlights, organic growth is the best option in this cycle as it by passes myriad problems that would arise from a merger of two healthy businesses and the doubtless greater problems where merging with a business that has highlighted its own trading pressures. Redrow’s share price had not been unduly impacted by the announcement that it would potentially make an offer so the withdrawal is unlikely to have a material impact on the share price but, if anything, there is the removal of the risk of a potentially damaging move that could push the shares ahead. Redrow is still trading below our fair value of 527p so we will be sticking with our BUY recommendation and the risk of step down in stance highlighted in our recent comments is now removed.

Redrow’s announcement might suggest that Bovis’ share price should step back sharply but while Redrow has stepped away, Galliford^ (GFRD, NR CNP at 1507p) remains interested in making an offer so Bovis remains in play. However, this move must put pressure on Galliford to make a decision about whether it will proceed. Even if it does decide to withdraw, even then Bovis’ share price does not automatically reset because it is still possible that a bid is launched from outside the sector, from the likes of a contracting business or an overseas player wanting to break into UK housing. However, the likelihood of an offer must now have reduced and there is a greater risk that Bovis’ valuation steps back towards its fundamental value based on its own trading. On this basis we only see fair value at 757p (the historic NAV) although using our core valuation methodology the true value should be more than 100p lower than this. However, we struggle to see the market allowing a house builder to trade below NAV in this cycle. Therefore, the NAV should describe a floor for the share price.

However, with the chances of any offer having diminished and with the share price visibly carrying a bid premium, we would recommend taking some profit in Bovis to mitigate against the risk of there being no bid.

11:40 am
Galliford Try PLC (GFRD:LSE): Last: 1,480, down 27 (-1.79%), High: 1,518, Low: 1,480, Volume: 83.46k
BE11:41am

H1's slightly better, LFL turning positive.

PM11:42am

It's becoming Ferguson plc ???

11:42 am

BE11:43am

More importantly, though, it's switching to $ reporting.

PM11:43am

And the name change is $-related

11:43 am
PM11:43am

We are announcing today that we will change the name of the Group to Ferguson plc from 31 July 2017, subject to shareholder approval. This will align the Group's name with our most significant brand in our largest market where we generate 84% of Group trading profit. The Ferguson brand has been in existence for over 60 years in the USA and is synonymous with high quality and great customer service. The Group will continue to maintain the Wolseley trading name in the UK and Canada where it has strong local recognition.

BE11:44am

Caz went along to the analyst presentation and here are their thoughts.

BE11:44am

While management unsurprisingly said that the group is very happy with its stable UK investor base and has no current plans to move its listing, we still expect the implications of and potential support for a relisting to remain at the forefront of discussions over coming weeks, given that US peers tend to trade on at least slightly higher multiples.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

We've talked about US relisting for a bunch of companies over here, Wolseley included. Though the only one I can remember doing the switch in recent times was GW Pharma.

BE11:45am

While Q2 US LFL beat our estimate (6.7% vs. 4.2%), performance Q3 to date is bang in line with our estimate at 5.5%. Q2 was reportedly helped by the timing of Christmas increasing the level of construction work done in December and Q3 has been diluted slightly by snow in March. However the bigger factor is that the guidance looks to be slightly softer on margin in the US. The margin was down in H1,as expected,. primarily driven by cost deflation resulting in difficulty covering the cost base. The group previously continued to guide to high single digit incremental margin for the full year, implying H2 would return to the usual guided level of ‘low-double-digit’, aided by price deflation ending. However, the group now expects a single digit incremental margin in H2, diluted by a higher cost base, on increased headcount. There’s now a hiring freeze in the US as the group looks to correct this position. However, we now see scope for consensus to factor in a small US margin decline y/y. While the UK is admirably better, the division is not big enough to drive upgrades, meaning overall we are not expecting consensus to move today.

BE11:46am

And Deutsche.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Company consensus is looking for EBITA of £1,087m, implying a H2 growth rate of c.13% and we estimate ~5% like for like so only limited operational gearing. We expect consensus may move up by the beat possibly more depending on how positive management are on operational gearing and volume growth Wolseley is at the top of its valuation range and trades on 16x calendar 17e P/E and 12x 17e EV/EBITA and as such we see limited re-rating potential. However, the company is delivering likely consensus upgrades and has a strong balance sheet. It should be able to hold its multiple on upgrades in the near term but remains Hold for now.

Cobham PLC (COB:LSE): Last: 127.60, up 0.8 (+0.63%), High: 127.80, Low: 124.20, Volume: 2.67m
11:49 am
PM11:49am

2-for-5 at 75p

PM11:50am

PM11:50am

Sorry no!

11:50 am
PM11:50am

PM11:50am

PM11:51am

11:51 am
PM11:51am

· The Rights Issue, which is subject to Shareholder approval, is fully underwritten by Merrill Lynch International (BofA Merrill Lynch) and J.P. Morgan Securities plc (which conducts its UK investment banking activities as J.P. Morgan Cazenove) acting as Joint Sponsors, Joint Bookrunners and Joint Underwriters, and Barclays Bank PLC, acting through its investment bank, acting as Co-Bookrunner and Joint Underwriter

BE11:51am

Anyway ......... in terms of the FCA, it looks probable that they're asking whether Cobham sat on market sensitive information to announce its last rights issue in conjunction with results.

BE11:51am

Which if accurate is ..... I dunno, maybe a bit fussy?

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Sandy Morris of Jefferies provided a handy timeline yesterday.

BE11:52am

On 11 January 2017, Cobham was able to provide a Post-close Trading Update. While the detailed year end close was ongoing, Cobham was able to indicate a Group trading profit of £245m, closing net debt of £1.03bn, and that it would not pay a final dividend in respect of 2016. In short, 8 working days after the financial year end, Cobham was able to paint a fairly accurate outcome. We wonder if the FCA has hence questioned whether Cobham could have known the 1Q16 trading profit and have announced it as early as 12 April 2016. Cobham might, perhaps, have waited to weigh up the implications for the balance sheet covenants and to consider the dividend policy before making the all-encompassing announcement of 26 April 2016. Our understanding is that price sensitive information should be disclosed by a company as soon as practicable.

BE11:53am

We have reviewed the fines imposed by the FCA (or FSA) between 2013 and 2016, of which very few appear germane to Cobham’s possible situation. In March 2013, however, a £16m financial penalty was imposed on The Prudential Assurance Company (PAC) for “failing to deal with the FSA in an open and cooperative manner and for failing to disclose appropriately information of which the FSA would reasonably expect notice”. In short, the FSA was not notified until 27 February 2010 by PAC that it was seeking to acquire AIA from AIG in early 2010. A second parallel is Lamprell, also from March 2013, although we hesitate to suggest the parallel with Cobham is great. In short, by 29 April 2012, the FSA asserted Lamprell’s management had sufficient information such that it should have at least issued a holding statement putting the market on notice of a potential material deterioration in its financial position. Lamprell issued a profit warning on 16 May 2012. Further, Lamprell managers were allowed deal in Lamprell shares in early May 2012. The FSA imposed on Lamprell a financial penalty of £2.4m

11:53 am
BE11:53am

All speculation, of course, but I do wonder if the FCA might have better things to spend our money pursuing.

PM11:53am

The Pru fine was utterly ridiculous

BE11:54am

Yup. Anyway, Sandy's back this morning on the rights news.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

[T]he dilution in FY17 and FY18 will inevitably be significant, in our view. Regardless, Cobham’s financial position will unquestionably be sound and potentially a springboard for good progress from FY18. In addition, we believe the recent US GAO report on KC-46 suggests Cobham’s challenges there should not be insurmountable.

BE11:55am

The KC-46 report is here, if you want it: http://www.gao.gov/assets/690/683688.pdf

BE11:56am

Here's what Jefferies makes of it.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

While we do not want to be complacent about the challenges facing Cobham on KC-46, we believe the GAO’s commentary is consistent with our argument that what is needed is a repair job, not a turnaround. It sounds like Cobham should be able to update us on progress at the 1H17 stage (if the FAA approves the WARP in July 2017). In our last note – 15 March 2017 – Respectful Space – we argued it was hard to model a scenario where Group FCF was negative in both FY17 and FY18. We note, for example, that at end FY16, WIP on customer funded engineering development contracts was almost unchanged at £58.4m. We believe that £58.4m may be reimbursed by the customer(s) at pre-agreed intervals or on achievement of pre-agreed development milestones. Even if we assume more or less full utilisation of the £147m contract loss provisions in place at end FY16, we struggle to model a scenario where FCF is negative in both FY17 and FY18. We recognise the notional dilution stemming from the Rights Issue – and estimated above – is quite significant, but we remain optimistic that Cobham will be back on the front foot in FY18 and hence would emphasise the word “notional”.

11:59 am

PM12:00pm

Marcus Aurelius was the last of the so-called Five Good Emperors. He was a practitioner of Stoicism, and his untitled writing, commonly known as Meditations, is the most significant source of the modern understanding of ancient Stoic philosophy.

undefined

Carillion PLC (CLLN:LSE): Last: 210.40, down 9.2 (-4.19%), High: 217.30, Low: 208.40, Volume: 2.96m
12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Jefferies negative.

BE12:03pm

We upgrade COST to Buy, but downgrade both CLLN and BBY to Hold. We favour COST’s simplified strategy, higher margins, greater contract certainty and stronger balance sheet. Though CLLN’s earnings outlook is solid, the Group’s balance sheet and pension deficit erode much of the value, while we believe BBY’s recovery story is now priced in.

BE12:03pm

Can’t Avoid the Elephant in the Room; Downgrading Carillion to Hold. Following the recent results, we reduced our FY17 and FY18 EPS estimates by 5% and 1%, reflecting slower bidding in the Support Services space, and we expect a flattish earnings outcome this year. Carillion’s narrative is dominated by its balance sheet, however. Average debt of £587m was £48m above 2015’s figure and combined with the pension deficit of £663m (itself up £262m vs June) accounts for c.£1.1bn of the Group’s EV. The Group is targeting debt reduction of £25-50m this year (included in mgmt. incentive plans), but this only scratches the surface. The shares trade at a significant discount (c.35%) to the sector and are, in our view, pricing in a rights issue to ease the balance sheet difficulties. While we view this as unlikely in the short term, we also see no need to actively own the shares at these levels.

12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

(@Lefere: history is easier to predict than future, I find.)

BE12:04pm

Pausing for Breath; Downgrade Balfour Beatty to Hold. The first phase of the turnaround is complete, with the losses in UK construction stemmed and the balance sheet repaired. The next stage of the journey sees the Group returning to industry standard margins by the end of 2018. We expect this to take the form of J-curve with a flattish top line boosted only by the US (mainly FX). Lower PPP disposal profits grabbed headlines immediately after the results, but, in our view, this is largely irrelevant to any SOTP valuation discussion. In our view, lower sales are a reflection of the Group’s confidence in the balance sheet and the earnings potential of the Construction businesses. Though we acknowledge the excellent delivery of the turnaround this far, with the shares trading at c.30% premiums to the peer group, we believe the next stage of the journey is largely priced in.
